posts.cooked:
Signal has many important options that increase its security and privacy, and which allow users follow best practices. But not everybody uses these options, and best practices (such as for deleting groups) can sometimes involve complicated algorithms that users must implement manually.

The internet is currently filling up with instructions about which options people can turn on to make their chats safer. Our group chats are often taken up by instructions for how to best protect each other. And the process of fully closing groups has become especially cumbersome - we have been taught to change the title of the group to things like ‚ÄúDELETE THIS GROUP‚Äù before removing everybody, and then hoping that people comply. And if we do things out of order, we are screwed.

I propose to make these things easier by letting group admins set a ‚Äútop secret‚Äù option. When set, all of signal‚Äôs extra protections against data leaks - such as prohibiting screenshots, not showing any content or metadata in notifications, not being included in backups - are enforced for all of that chat‚Äôs content, even if members have more permissive default options for their other chats.

In a top secret chat, the disappearing messages timer can still be changed, but it‚Äôs impossible to turn it off.

In a top secret chat, at any time the admin has the power to nuke it, which means: automatically remove all members, and automatically DELETE THE CHAT FROM ALL DEVICES. not just the messages, but the metadata, description, join/part/rename scrollback, everything. users can be warned of this possibility before they join a top secret chat. perhaps the UI could also show a notification to explain that a chat has been deleted, or even a parting message from the admin.

Perhaps the chat could even be self-destructing, ie everybody is warned in advance, that the nuking will happen automatically at a scheduled time.

What I am proposing is not security theater. It does not try to solve the problem of ‚Äúuntrusted‚Äù chat users, which of course would be a technical solution to a social problem.

What I‚Äôm proposing is that some of the common practices and routines of well-organized groups be automated. Sometimes these practices can be tedious or fragile, and one accidental wrong step can lead to errors or opsec leakage.

The purpose of computers is to make our lives easier. In my experience, the process of enforcing security policies for our orgs has grown overwhelming for many users, even those who want to comply, but just find the instructions too confusing.

I don‚Äôt think this proposal is invasive. The group admin can only remove data from your device when it‚Äôs part of a ‚Äútop secret chat‚Äù, and you were warned ahead of time when you joined it.

Perhaps to cause less surprise or confusion, the group admin cannot delete the chat immediately, but can set a deletion timer with a minimum of 3 days, say. Users could choose to delete it earlier too. Maybe an informational message would hang around for longer saying ‚Äúa group was deleted‚Äù.

More detailed answers to your post below:

Anything sent to a secret chat will only stay in the secret chat without the ability to save to the device, screenshot or screen recording.

When creating a secret chat with a person, you will be able to choose the self-destruction time of messages and all media in the chat, for example from 1 minute to 7 days.

razerock:

As I said earlier, everything sent to a secret chat will remain there, without the ability to copy (even text), forward, save to phone (media), screenshots and screen recording.

razerock:
